Award.AwardTitle: Growth and Structure of Multifunctional Polymer Brushes from Ultra-thin Coatings
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymer brushes are long stringy molecules that are chemically bonded to a surface to form dense, thin coatings that drastically change the properties of the surface. These coatings guide the behavior of cells for regenerative medicine, promote biocompatibility in implant devices, resist deposition of micro-organisms on ship hulls, or control flow of electricity in microelectronic devices. The structure of the polymer brushes provides the needed mechanical strength to form a stable coating and their chemistry provides the right functionality to interface/communicate between the substrate and the environment. This research program will develop new synthetic methodologies to make these polymer brushes and develop materials characterization techniques to promote a molecular-level understanding of the resulting structures. This methodology has the potential to be of broad impact since the chemistry is simple enough to be adapted by the coatings industries. The research program will serve to inspire and involve undergraduate students in polymer science and engineering research, by working with the PI and graduate student mentors through the REU program. K-12 educational modules developed through this research will be disseminated nationally by the PI and the graduate students by partnering with UW-Madison Institute for Chemical Education (ICE). Through the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Residential Program the PI will engage in mentoring underrepresented students to create a supportive environment by coordinating information, research and activities for and about women in the sciences and engineering.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The research program will study the synthesis of a single-component crosslinked coating to grow homopolymers and mixed polymer brushes with excellent control over homogeneity of grafting sites, dispersities, chemical functionalities, graft to graft distance, ability to grow low to high molecular weights, and with stability to thermal annealing conditions. The growth of polymer brushes from these coatings is fundamentally different from growth from traditional self-assembled monolayers. A key aspect of this research will be to develop a mechanistic understanding of the growth process by combining depth profiling and angle resolved X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (ARXPS) studies. The stratification effect as well as brush growth kinetics will be studied as a function of crosslink density and coating thickness by embedding specific elemental markers in the brush (Br and N). Combination of ARXPS, Atomic force microscopy and 3D tomography will provide useful morphological information on these polymer brushes. The brushes grown from these coatings will be floated off from the substrate as "polymer carpets" and 3D morphological insight obtained by 3D tomography. Melt self-consistent field theory (SCFT) predictions of phase diagrams for mixed polymer brushes are based on the assumption that the grafting densities are uniform. So far experimental means for meeting these assumptions have lagged behind. Using the unique chemistry for growth of well-defined brushes and the characterization methods developed in this proposal the SCFT predictions will be tested. Furthermore the simplicity of the chemistry is expected to allow arbitrary changes in composition to tune surface properties by incorporating appropriate comonomers. For these reasons the methodology developed here has the potential to have major impact by highly simplifying the way polymer brushes are grown.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Macromolecular chains anchored onto various interfaces and surfaces have long been known to influence interfacial properties such as wetting, transport, and adhesion in many natural and biological systems. Taking cues from nature the polymer community has studied synthetic polymer brushes that are essentially long chain molecules chemically bonded to the surface to form coatings that alter  the properties of the surface. If more than two types of polymer chains are anchored to the substrate, the resulting mixed brushes can display a complex set of morphologies in response to external stimuli such as heat, light or pH.  Many of these morphologies have been predicted in theory but not fully realized experimentally. This is largely because the current synthetic approaches offer limited control over grafting density, uniformity,  stability and length of the grafted polymer chains. We addressed this problem by developing a copolymer that can be applied to a wide range of surfaces and crosslinked to create an ultra-thin coating. The copolymer has two different types of embedded initiators that can grow dense mixed polymer brushes with exceptional control over the composition, that are also stable to subsequent annealing conditions. As a result, we demonstrated for the first time that mixed polymer brushes with extended polymer chain conformation can display the morphologies predicted by phase diagrams in the melt phase. The methodology developed in this grant is broadly  applicable for the synthesis of mixed polymer brushes, where the two brushes have a large mismatch in their surface energies, leading to more complex microphase separated structures. We also developed a sacrificial layer chemistry to detach the as-grown polymer brushes from the surface to measure their molecular weights by traditional methods. We further developed  an empirical model to relate the height of the first brush and the height increment after the growth of the second brush to their respective grafting densities. The resulting morphologies upon thermal annealing were characterized by complementary information derived from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and emerging cutting-edge methods such as Resonant Soft- X-ray scattering methods.  These studies uncovered the critical role played by the polymer chain-end functional groups in dictating the morphology. The synthetic methodology developed in this grant, along with the characterization techniques effectively help bridge the gap between theory and experiments in the field of polymer mixed brushes. The research program has resulted in graduation of two Ph.D students, one Masters student, and research experience for many undergraduate students in polymer science and engineering, by working with graduate student mentors.
